text: [Music]
hello and thank you for watching
how to set up a csv pipeline for a dot
net application
with aws code pipeline and aws elastic
bin stock
i am sanjay gulati senior partner
solutions architect here at amazon web
services
with elastic bin stock you can easily
host dotnet web applications
without needing to launch configure or
operate any virtual servers on your own
and using aws code pipeline you can set
up
an automated release cycle for a fast
and reliable application updates to
elastic bin stop
there are generally four major phases of
the release process
source build test and deploy and with
aws code pipeline you can automate all
the phases of the release process
to rapidly and reliably deliver features
and updates
aws score pipeline can be easily
integrated with other aws code services
such as aws code commit for the source
control repository
aws code build to build and test your
application
aws code deploy to deploy your
application to a production environment
and you can also perform blue green
deployment to avoid any application
downtime
and all these aws code services are
fully managed services
and you only pay for what you use there
are no upfront fees or any long-term
commitments
aws code pipeline can also be integrated
with other third-party services
such as github for source control
jenkins to do
your build and run unit tests or you can
also integrate with your own custom
plugins
so let's take a look at what our
pipeline is going to look like in this
video
first we are going to host our source
code in aws code commit
then we are going to set up the pipeline
so that whenever we commit our change in
the code commit
it will trigger our aws code pipeline to
build the application run unit test
and deploy the application to elastic
bin stop so let's get started
here i am in user studio running on my
windows box
and i have the aws toolkit for visual
studio installed
also to keep the demo simple i have the
default aws profile setup
on my local machine with full admin
access to aws services
for your production purposes i would
recommend to follow the leashed
privilege principle
and only assign the permissions that
your developer needs
to save some time in the demo i have the
sample web application already created
using visualstudio.net core web
application project templates
this is a very simple dotnet core web
application that we will use for our
demo
and deploy to elastic bean stock using
aws code services
let's go ahead and run this application
locally to make sure the project builds
and runs successfully
here you can see this is a simple veneer
web application
let's go back to virtual studio and look
at what else we have in our demo
application
here we also have some simple dummy unit
tests
that don't really do much but they will
give us
three passing tests and one failing test
because of the bad uri exception
we will see more about running the unit
test as a part of a cicd pipeline
later in the video there are two more
plain text files
added at the root location of the
project and to follow along with this
demo
you can download these files from the
displayed link
let's look at those files first file is
called a process file
this is the configuration file that is
internally used by elastic beanstalk
to identify the process that it should
run for your application
here we are telling elastic bean stock
that go ahead and execute the dotnet
executable
with the application dll as a parameter
and we are also configuring the url
where the app should run at the second
file is a build spec file
this file is internally used by aws
codebear
which does the actual compilation
essentially
it launches a container using a docker
image
then it runs a series of commands to
install any required software
and perform the actual build or the test
that you want it to run
let's walk through the build spec
commands here you can see there are four
phases
defined for the sample application the
first command executed in the install
phase
is to install the.net core 3.1 runtime
then in the pre-built phase it runs the
command to restore the nuget packages
in build phase it builds the application
and run the unit test
and for the code bill to report the test
we need to specify the logger format
and where to put the logs here in the
demo i have changed the dotnet test
command
to use the trx log format and to put the
results
in the test result directory and in the
post build phase
we are executing command to publish the
sample application
and copy the proc file to the build
output directory
finally in the artifacts node specify
the files that you want the code build
to compress
and provide to the code pipeline in the
sample
we are including all the files from the
build output directory
and to have the code build use the trx
files
to create the test report we need to add
the report section
this report section grab all of the xml
files
in the test result directory to generate
the test report
under the report group in the code pair
and we will see the reports in our demo
later in the video
now as we are familiar with the sample
application
let's go ahead and check in the sample
application to aws code commit
repository
the easiest way to do it is by using aws
toolkit
for visual studio let's go to the team
explorer
and find aws code commit choose connect
if you have a multiple aws profile
configured on your machine
then select the profile that you want to
use for the code commit
and then select ok once it's connected
successfully
then it will show up as a managed
connection and then choose create
aws code commit repositories are
organized by region
so select the region where you want your
code commit repository to be created
for this demo i will select the node
virginia region
in name enter the name of the repository
i am going to name it as
aws elastic bean stock cicd pipeline
in clone into enter or browse the folder
or directory where you want to clone
this repository
on your local computer i am going to
leave the default path as
is and then choose ok aws code commit is
just a git repository so we need to
generate the git credentials
for the code commit user for that
let's go back to the browser and
navigate to the imuser page
in aws console click on the user that
you're using for code commit
and then select the security credentials
tab and then generate the git
credentials for aws code commit
download the csv file containing the
credentials
and then let's go back to the visual
studio
click to import from csv file and locate
the file
that you just downloaded on your local
machine
and then select ok once the repository
is created and cloned successfully
it will show up as a local git
repository
next we want to copy the source code of
the sample application
to this empty git repository and check
it in using git cli
for that right click on the clone
repository under the local git
repositories
and choose open command prompt copy the
path of the sample application
and then x copy the files into the local
git repository
and check it in using git cli
next let's go to the team explorer and
open the solution
from the new clone directory and to
avoid any confusion with the source code
directory
let's go to the file explorer
delete the old directory that had the
previous code next
we need to manually create the elastic
bin stock application
as the code pipeline deployment provider
for elastic bean stock
deploys to an existing application
environment
the easiest way to do this is using aws
toolkit
for visual studio so right click on the
project
and click publish to elastic bean stock
on the wizard choose the aws account
profile that you want to use for the
deployment
from the region drop-down list choose
the region i am going to use
us east north virginia region to deploy
the application
in the deployment target choose create a
new application environment to perform
an initial deployment of an
application on the application
environment page
you can specify the application name i
am going to leave the default name as is
and choose the development environment
check the availability for the url
as this needs to be unique for the
elastic beam stock to host your website
if the url for your website is ok then
choose next
on the aws option page you can choose
either windows
or linux but i'm going to select linux
since this is a dotnet core application
and it supports linux for key pair
i already have the bean stock tpl
created
and if you don't have an existing key
pair then go ahead and create one
and select that key pair from the drop
down and we can leave all the defaults
as is
on the permission page select deployment
role
that application will use to interact
with other aws services
and service role that bean stock will
use to monitor the application
i am going to leave the default value
for the deployment and the service role
as
is and choose next
on the application option page change
the project build to release
and change the rewards proxy to none to
use castro
as an internet facing web server
on the review page review your changes
and select
deploy the information about the
deployment will appear in the status bar
and the output window the deployment may
take several minutes
so i'm going to pause the video and
restart once the deployment is
successful
here we are the deployment to elastic
beam stock took around two minutes
let's go ahead and set up the automated
cac d pipeline
go back to the browser and browse to aws
code pipeline in the aws console
and click create new pipeline let's name
the pipeline as aws
elastic bean stock cicd pipeline
i i'm going to leave all the remaining
defaults as is
here it's going to create a new role for
code pipeline to use
and set s3 as a default artifact
and use aws kms for encryption
choose next for the source provider
choose aws code commit select the
repository
and then select master branch for
detection mode
what it's asking is how you want to
trigger your pipeline when the change is
detected in your source code
if you select aws code pipeline then it
will periodically check for the code
changes
and if you detect any change then it
will trigger the pipeline
else it will not do anything but
aws cloud watch is more efficient as
it's more of a event based model
where it will trigger the pipeline
automatically whenever the code change
is checked in
so i'm going to leave the aws cloud
watch at the change detection option
for build select aws code build and
select the region
i am going to leave it as north virginia
and choose
create new code build project
name the code build project for
consistency i will name it as
aws elastic bean stock code build
project
next we select the environment for
dotnet core application
let's select the manage images for
operating system
select amazon linux and select standard
for runtimes and the latest available
image
for service role leave the default value
this role will provide the aws code
build
the permissions to perform the build and
push the artifacts to the s3 bucket
under build spec select the use build
spec file
this is the file that we added earlier
to our source code repository
under logs enter the group name i'm
going to name it as
aws.net app csd logs
for the amazon cloud watch logs
this will output the detailed build logs
for each build
to the cloud watch i'm going to leave
the rest of settings as they are
click continue to code pipeline to save
the code build configuration
and return to the core pipeline wizard
and then click next
under deploy provider select aws elastic
bin stop
as the deploy provider for region i will
select
not virginia in the application name
field select the elastic bin stock
application that we previously deployed
to
and select the environment that we also
previously deployed to
then click next review all your settings
and click
create pipeline within a few moments the
source stage in your pipeline should
move to in progress
it can take around 10 minutes or more
for the build stage to complete
and then the deploy stage should finish
quickly
so i'm going to pause the video here and
then come back once the build stage is
complete
here we are back in the pipeline the
build process took around 3 minutes
and it's in a failed status which also
failed our pipeline
let's look at the build details
build failed because one of the unit
tests failed so let's go to the reports
tab
for more details about the unit tests
here you can see one unit test failed
because of the bad url exception
let's go back to the visual studio and
delete this unit test
now as we're in visual studio let's also
go and update the index page
and change the message from welcome
to welcome to beanstalk
and check in changes theoretically
this should automatically trigger our
pipeline let's go back to browser
and check the pipeline status
look like the pipeline is triggered
already and is in progress
as the pipeline can take few minutes i
am going to pause the video again
and restart when the deploy stays
complete
deployed to beanstalk just completed
successfully
let's check the url to verify the
updates
here we see the updated index page that
we committed earlier
through visual studio and it's got
deployed successfully from
code services thank you for watching
and have a great day
[Music]
